We have seen how to describe and express the conic sections using rectangular equations. Next we will see how to express the conic sections using parametric equations.

Circles

We have already seen circles from a parametric point of view. When we think of the unit circle \(x^2+y^2=1\), recall that we define the cosine of an angle \(\theta\) to be the \(x\)-coordinate of the point on the unit circle corresponding to the standard position angle \(\theta\) and define the sine of the angle \(\theta\) to be the \(y\)-coordinate of that point.

Rather than using the variable \(\theta\), let us use the variable \(t\). Then the points on the unit circle can be expressed using the parametric equation(s) \((x,y)=(\cos t,\sin t)\).

What if we wanted parametric equations for the circle centered at the origin, but with radius \(r\)? Then \((x,y)=(r\cos t,r\sin t)\) is just what we need: \[x^2+y^2=(r\cos t)^2+(r\sin t)^2 = r^2(\cos^2 t+\sin^2 t)=r^2.\]

What if we want to shift to a different center \((h,k)\)? Just shift the \(x\)-coordinate by \(h\) and the \(y\)-coordinate by \(k\): \((x,y)=(h+r\cos t,k+r\sin t)\). Notice that \[(x-h)^2+(y-k)^2=(r\cos t)^2+(r\sin t)^2=r^2.\]

Parametric Equations for a Circle

The circle with center \((h,k)\) and radius \(r\) can be expressed using parametric equations as follows: \[(x,y)=(h+r\cos t,k+r\sin t)\text{ with } 0\leq t\leq 2\pi.\]

Ellipses

Ellipses are not very difficult either. For the ellipse \(\frac{x^2}{a^2}+\frac{y^2}{b^2}=1\), suppose we let \((x,y)=(a\cos t,b\sin t)\). Then \[\frac{x^2}{a^2}+\frac{y^2}{b^2}=\frac{(a\cos t)^2}{a^2}+\frac{(b\sin t)^2}{b^2}=\cos^2 t + \sin^2 t = 1.\] This is exactly what we need!

We can also do a similar trick as we did with circles to shift the center of an ellipse.

Parametric Equations for an Ellipse

The ellipse with standard equation \(\frac{(x-h)^2}{a^2}+\frac{(y-k)^2}{b^2}=1\) can be can be expressed using parametric equations as follows: \[(x,y)=(h+a\cos t,k+b\sin t)\text{ with } 0\leq t\leq 2\pi.\]

The ellipse with standard equation \(\frac{(x-h)^2}{b^2}+\frac{(y-k)^2}{a^2}=1\) can be can be expressed using parametric equations as follows: \[(x,y)=(h+b\cos t,k+a\sin t)\text{ with } 0\leq t\leq 2\pi.\]

Hyperbolas

Hyperbolas are more difficult. We have basically used up our trick that \(\cos^2 t+\sin^2 t=1\) for the functions \(x=\cos t\) and \(y=\sin t\) to get parametric equations for circles and ellipses. To get parametric equations for hyperbolas, we need to find functions where \(x^2-y^2=1\).

Consider the functions \(h_1(x)=\frac{e^x+e^{-x}}{2}\) and \(h_2=\frac{e^x-e^{-x}}{2}\). Notice that \[ (h_1(x))^2-(h_2(x))^2=\left(\frac{e^x+e^{-x}}{2}\right)^2-\left(\frac{e^x-e^{-x}}{2}\right)^2=\left(\frac{e^{2x}}{4}+\frac{1}{2}+\frac{e^{-2x}}{4}\right)-\left(\frac{e^{2x}}{4}-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{e^{-2x}}{4}\right)=1.\]

So if we were to let \(x=\frac{e^t+e^{-t}}{2}\) and \(y=\frac{e^t-e^{-t}}{2}\), then we would have parametric equations where \(x^2-y^2=1\), which is exactly what we need to parametrize hyperbolas!.

These functions have special names. We call \(\frac{e^t+e^{-t}}{2}\) the hyperbolic cosine and denote it by \(\cosh(t)\). We call \(\frac{e^t+e^{-t}}{2}\) the hyperbolic sine and denote it by \(\sinh(t)\). These two functions have other bizarro-world similarities to sine and cosine, with just a difference in sign in places.

But what is important to us is that \((x,y)=(a\cosh(t),b\sinh(t))\) is a parametrization of \(\frac{x^2}{a^2}-{y^2}{b^2}=1\) as follows: \[\frac{x^2}{a^2}-\frac{y^2}{b^2}=\frac{a^2\cosh^2(t)}{a^2}+\frac{b^2\sinh^2(t)}{b^2}=\cosh^2(t)-\sinh^2(t)=1.\] This gives us the right branch of the hyperbola. Notice that since it is a graph with infinite length, we will let \(t\) range over all real numbers.

Now we have parametric equations for hyperbolas:

Parametric Equations for the Right Branch of a Horizontal Hyperbola

The hyperbola with standard equation \(\frac{(x-h)^2}{a^2}+\frac{(y-k)^2}{b^2}=1\) can be can be expressed using parametric equations as follows: \[(x,y)=(h+a\cosh t,k+b\sinh t).\]

Parabolas

Parabolas are the second easy parametrization other than circles. While there are more complicated ways to do it: we can let \(x\) or \(y\) be \(t\) and solve the standard or general equation for the other variable.

For example, with the parabola \((x-2)^2=12(y-3)\), we may let \(x=t\) and the solve \((t-2)^2=12(y-3)\) for \(y\) to get \(y=3+\frac{(t-2)^2}{12}\). Thus our parametrization is \((x,y)=\left(t,3+\frac{(t-2)^2}{12}\right)\).

Parametric Equations for Parabolas

The parabola with standard equation \((x-h)^2=\pm 4c(y-k)\) can be can be expressed using parametric equations as follows: \[(x,y)=\left(t,k\pm\frac{(t-h)^2}{4c}\right).\]

The parabola with standard equation \((y-k)^2=\pm 4c(x-h)\) can be can be expressed using parametric equations as follows: \[(x,y)=\left(h\pm\frac{(t-k)^2}{4c},t\right).\]
